Question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?

Context: 

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice
cultivation is conducted in Dayi County within Chengdu City, Sichuan Province of China,
with a total acreage of 12,514 ha for single-cropping rice. Without the implementation of
this project, the continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice
was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic
matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH ) 4
because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to
water conservation, production increase and methane emission reduction than the
continuously flooded.
This project solved the problems of excessive water used during rice cultivation which
results in not only large amount of methane (CH ) emissions but also low rice productivity 4
by replacing the continuously flooded method with intermittent flooded method, which
shortens the period of anaerobic decomposition of soil organic matter.In this case, the CH 4
emission can be declined by an average of 48%1. Hence, with the proposed project activity,
an estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 4.58 tCO e/ha for single-cropping rice is 2
expected. Annual average estimation of GHG emission reductions from the project activity
is 57,352 tCO e/year, and the total GHG emission reductions are 573,520 tCO e during the 2 2
fixed 10 years crediting period.
This project aims to:
- Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes;
- Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers;
- Increase the number of local individuals who have relevant skills due to diversified
educational opportunities from trainings;
- Provide more job opportunities, especially women workers.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The project is developed under VCS scope 14 “Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use
(AFOLU)” with an activity category of Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under
1Dr. Reiner Wassmann (2016). Coordinator, Climate Change Research. International Rice Research
Institute. Available from: r.wassmann@irri.org

project is within the boundary of the national power grid of ONEE.
2.4 Baseline Scenario
According to the approved methodology ACM0002, if the project activity is the installation of a
new grid-connected renewable power plant/unit, the baseline scenario is the following:
Electricity delivered to the grid by the project activity would have otherwise been generated by the
operation of grid-connected power plants and by the addition of new generation sources, as
reflected in the combined margin (CM) calculations described in the “Tool to calculate the
emission factor for an electricity system”.
Thus the baseline scenario is the supply of equivalent annual power output by the national
electricity grid.

Sustainable Development

sustainable development for satisfying of the sustainability criteria. The pillars of

shortage around 8.8% at national level.

SECTION A. General description of project activity
A.1 Title of the project activity:
Gansu Yumen Diwopu Phase II Wind Power Project
Version: 3.0.

A.2. Description of the project activity:
The Gansu Yumen Diwopu phase II Wind Power Project (hereinafter refers to the proposed project) is a
grid connected renewable energy in Yumen Town,Yumen City, Gansu Province, P.RChina(hereafter
referred to as the “Host Country”). It involves the installation of 33 turbines, each of which has a rated
output of 1500kW, providing a total installed capacity of 49.5 MW, with a predicted power supplied to
the grid of 113,800 MW annually.
The purpose of the project is to generate power through wind energy thereby reducing greenhouse
gas(GHG) emissions in electricity generation in the Northwest China Power Grid(NWCPG). The
proposed project is therefore expected to reduce emissions of GHG by an estimated amount of 105,754
tonnes of CO2 per year.
The baseline scenario of the proposed project is the additional power generated by NWCPG, and it is the
same as the existing scenario prior to start of the implementation of the project activity. As the NWCPG
is dominated by the thermal power generation, the proposed projects activity will achieve greenhouse
gas(GHG) emission reductions by displacing the electricity from NWCPG.
The project activity will promote the local and national sustainable development powerfully in the
following aspects:
¤ Achieves GHG emission reductions by avoiding electricity generation from fossil fuel-fired
power;
¤ Increase employment opportunities in the area where the project located(approximately 4
people1 will be permanently employed for the project operation, besides, the construction of the
project will provide job vacancies ) and thereby contributes to the local economy;
¤ Help to stimulate the growth of the wind power industry in China;
¤ The proposed project could be helpful to diversify power structure of Northwest China Power
Grid and reduce the dependence on exhaustible fossil fuels for power generation.

Purpose of the project activity
The project activity is being implemented in the Karnal district of Haryana at the rice milling facility
of Best Foods Limited (hereafter known as BFL). BFL is a renowned player in the country
engaged in the business of rice shelling and its exports with a production capacity of around 1600
Tonnes per day (TPD). The purpose of the project activity is implementation of a 6 MW biomass
(rice husk) based cogeneration plant to cater to the demand for steam and electricity for captive
consumption
Salient Features of the project activity
The proposed project activity involves installation of a cogeneration plant comprising of one rice
husk fired AFBC boiler with steam generation capacity of 50 TPH at 67 kg/cm2 (a) pressure
and 480±5˚ C temperature and a 6 MW extraction cum condensing steam turbine generator. The
project activity is expected to produce around 47.52 GWh of net electrical output per annum.
Project Scenario
The project utilizes biomass (rice husk) generated from nearby rice mills to generate
electricity and steam for captive consumption in a co-generation unit. The design of the
project equipments allows use of following fuels:
1. Rice husk (to the extent of 100%)
2. Sub bituminous coal in case of exigencies (during start up)
The project was conceived considering usage of 100% rice husk as fuel and emission
reduction is estimated considering the same.

Question: What is the methodology of this project?

Context: 

Joint Project Description & Monitoring Report: VCS Version 4.2
● Harvest or commercial thinning
● Round wood transport
These activities generate an impact on the stakeholders since they generate concern about the
contamination in the nearby water courses, damage to the bees, intoxication of the workers who
apply pesticides, damage to the properties of the neighbours. Due to these concerns, CLIMIT
decides to address these impacts through an assessment and act.
The evaluation consists of:
1. Identify and evaluate with the stakeholders (such as: the president of the promotion
commission, teachers, those in charge of the polyclinics, neighbours, others) the impacts
of these activities.
2. Then, an analysis is carried over to identify which preventive or mitigating measures can
be implemented.
3. The project owner is informed of the measures taken.
4. Lastly, regular contact is maintained with stakeholders to assess the effectiveness of the
measures.
It is important for CLIMIT that stakeholders participate in the identification and evaluation of
impacts and their corresponding measures to mitigate the impact, since this allows the
stakeholder to have the opportunity to contribute or resolve their doubts and that the measures
taken to mitigate the impact are agreed between all parties.
Once an agreement is reached to mitigate the impacts of the mentioned activities, the project
owner and proponent must inform the stakeholders of the activity to be carried out with its
corresponding scope and ways of working of the activity to be developed. Then they should
explain the preventive measures that will be carried out for this activity.
3 A M PPLICATION OF ETHODOLOGY
3.1 Title and Reference of Methodology
The methodology applied is AR-ACM0003 “A/R Large-scale Consolidated Methodology:
Afforestation and reforestation of lands except wetlands” (Version 02.0). The A/R
methodological tools used are the following:
1. Version 01 of AR-TOOL02 “Combined tool to identify the baseline scenario and
demonstrate additionality in A/R CDM project activities”.
2. Version 04.2 of AR-TOOL14 “Estimation of carbon stocks and change in carbon stocks of
trees and shrubs in A/R CDM project activities”.
3. Version 03.1 of AR-TOOL12 “Estimation of carbon stocks and change in carbon stocks in
dead wood and litter in A/R CDM project activities”.
50

Joint Project Description & Monitoring Report: VCS Version 4.2
4. Version 01.1.0 of AR-TOOL16 “Tool for estimation of change in soil organic carbon stocks
due to the implementation of A/R CDM project activities”.
5. Version 04.0.0 of AR-TOOL08 “Estimation of non-CO2 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions
resulting from burning of biomass attributable to an A/R CDM project activity”.
6. Version 02.0 of AR-TOOL15 “Estimation of the increase in GHG emissions attributable to
displacement of pre-project agricultural activities in A/R CDM project activity”.
3.2 Applicability of Methodology
The project activities meet the applicability conditions of the methodology given that:
● The project area does not correspond to wetland, but instead to grasslands under beef-
cattle grazing.
● Given that the soils in the project are not organic, and the grassland cover is moderately
degraded with low to null inputs, soil disturbance is not restricted, However, it must be
noted that the disturbance is minimal given both that the tillage necessary for the planting
of the trees is localised (wide corridors which are not planted reduce the net area) and the
distance between rows is higher than in a typical high-density plantation.
The applicability conditions of the tools are met as well:
1. No laws are being violated through the project activities. As a project, the afforestation
and reforestation activities are not considered small-scale, for it is a grouped project
which will include multiple instances of the silvopastoral systems with CO sequestration 2
in the tree biomass.
2. Soil disturbance may occur every 14-20 years only if replanting activities happens
following the timber harvest. The land preparation at that moment will not occur at the
same place, but between the rows. New trees are planted in the alleyways, which have not
been disturbed for at least 28-40 years. Some other projects will manage the natural
regrowth occurring from the stump and land disturbance will not happen in 28-40 years.
3. No fire is used for land preparation or clearance; therefore the tool will only be used in the
case of an accidental forest fire.
4. There is not displacement of activities which would result in drainage of wetlands or
peatlands.

Version 1.7
1 Description of Project:
1.1 Project title
INFAPRO Rehabilitation of logged-over dipterocarp forest in Sabah, Malaysia
1.2 Type/Category of the project
IFM - LtHP
AFOLU Improved Forest Management. Conversion of Low Productive to High Productive
Forest by climber cutting and enrichment planting and prevention of unsustainable logging.
1.3 Estimated amount of emission reductions over the crediting period
including project size:
It is estimated that project results into a net emission reduction benefit of 4,140,409 tCO -e 2
within a Crediting Period of 30 years in a rehabilitated area of 25,000 hectares. This value is
not corrected for a non-permanence buffer.
1.4 A brief description of the project:
The project rehabilitates 25,000 ha of severely logged-over mixed dipterocarp rainforest in
Sabah, Malaysia and prevents relogging of the forest in this area. In the absence of the project
activity, the forest would be re-logged and would only slowly recuperate due to the high
quantities of vines and climbing bamboos suppressing the remnant trees and the natural
regeneration process.
The project is called INFAPRO which is an acronym for Innoprise-Face Foundation
Rainforest Rehabilitation Project. INFAPRO is the collaborative project between Rakyat
Berjaya and Face the Future. Rakyat Berjaya is responsible for the field project, which
contains implementation and management of the forest rehabilitation activities. Face the
Future holds the carbon sequestration rights and is responsible for the carbon development
aspect of the project.
In 1992 Rakyat Berjaya and the Face Foundation (the predecessor of Face the Future) signed
a contract with the objective of carbon sequestration through the joint implementation of an
enrichment planting forestry project on Yayasan Sabah’s now largely logged-over concession,
in direct vicinity of the Danum Valley Conservation Area. The resulting INFAPRO project is
a large-scale rainforest rehabilitation project aimed at the rehabilitation of 25,000 ha of
heavily degraded logged-over rainforest. In doing so, the project enables the sequestration of
large volumes of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, thus combating climate change.
INFAPRO is supported by the Government of Sabah in a Memorandum of Understanding
between the State of Sabah and Face.
The INFAPRO project is divided into two phases. The first is the implementation phase
which covers the first three years of each contract and is under the shared financial
responsibility of Face the Future and Rakyat Berjaya. Activities within this phase are
implemented by Rakyat Berjaya. The second phase is the subsequent management phase,
which covers the following 96 years, which is under responsibility of Rakyat Berjaya. As a
whole, the project results in the prevention of short-term re-logging and rehabilation of a
severely degraded logged-over rainforest.

Question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?

Context: 

CCB + VCS PROJECT DESCRIPTION
CCB Version 3, VCS Version 3
2.1.10 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The project will be developed under VCS scope 14 ’Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use
(AFOLU)’with a project category of Afforestation, Reforestation and Revegetation (ARR). The project is
not a grouped project.
2.1.11 Project Activities and Theory of Change (G1.8)
The project aims to increase carbon sequestration and contribute to local sustainable development by
planting trees on the barren hill and degraded lands. 50,061ha (705,916 Mu) of forest were directly
afforested on degraded lands in Zunyi City, including 1 district and 7 counties: Bozhou district, Tongzhi
county, Suiyang county, Zheng’an county, Daozhen county, Wuchuan county, Meitan county, Xishui
county. According to the Biodiversity Survey Report of the project, all the project areas were previously
barren land without agricultural activities. There was no natural renewal and reforestation before the
project, and some sites were covered by sparse shrub. Therefore, the project does not include activities
that convert native ecosystems to generate GHG credits, which means the eligibility criteria of VCS
AFOLU projects are fulfilled.
The species of ecological public welfare forest in the karst area mainly include Pine, China fir, Cypress,
Toonasinersis, Populusadenopoda, Dodonaeaviscosa, etc.. Among them Pine, China fir and Cypress are
the main forest species to control karst rocky desertification in Guizhou, because they have strong
adaptability Guizhou. Pine and China fir, Cypress are prominent in rocky desertification areas due to their
fast growth, shallow rooting and strong adaptability to the soil. They are all suitable afforestation species
in limestone mountainous areas of subtropical monsoon climate zone.
The implementation of the project would generate GHG emission removals and improve local
environment through growing trees, enhancing the capabilities of local communities and residents by
providing their relevant technical skills and training, and increasing local biodiversity by establishing a
forest of native trees (China fir, Cypresses, Pinus yunnanensis and Masson pine).
The project is estimated to generate GHG emission removals of 21,225,014 tCO e in 29 years, with an 2
average annual GHG emission removal of 731,897 tCO e. 2
Theory of Change
As explained in the following sections, the without project scenario may have three focal issues:
(1) Continued low activity and interaction of local communities and community groups;
(2) Degraded welfare conditions due to invasion of rocky desertification into the settlements of local
communities;
(3) Threat local climate conditions and biodiversity due to continued rocky desertification.

The project sequesters CO2 through forest plantation in degraded grassland areas, generating net
anthropogenic removals by sinks. The long-term average GHG benefit (LTA) is determined by averaging
the expected total GHG benefit for the length of the project (100 years: from 30/10/2016 – until
30/10/2116). The project will remove a total amount (LTA) of 2,021,823 tCO2 during a period of 100
years. This means an average of 20,218 tCO2 per year (estimated annual emission reductions and
removals). The financing of the project is achieved through a Trust fund that invests in land, forestry
plantation and management activities. These investors look for safe and predictable rates of return
wherein carbon certification is a plus to guarantee these attributes. The project contributes to the
sustainable development of Uruguay, specifically by:
• Increasing labour demand from the local population: the common activity developed in the
project region is livestock production. Besides the forestry plantation activities, the project will
maintain the cattle raising both on the unplanted area and under its plantations from year 2 to
the end (any local researchers support cattle breading inside forests as animals suffer less
temperature stress and for storms protection). This will generate a much larger demand of labour
when compared to these activities being developed separately.
• Adding value to wood products and diversifying the regional production will lead to higher
economic revenues for the region.
• Contribute to create a new sustainable resource into the country, that will allow the development
of new processing facilities in an economically depressed area.
• Increase the demand of scientists to investigate issues like plagues, biodiversity, forests growth
modelling, etc.
• Promoting an integrated management scheme with the ecosystem. In this sense, the plantations
already obtained the necessary approval from the DINACEA (National Directorate of Environment)
and the plantations are certified under the FSC standard.
• Developing and improving a new mechanism to finance projects in the forestry sector.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The activity implemented by the project is the establishment of forests on land that had previously been
under grassland, and therefore corresponds to the VCS scope 14: “Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land
Use” as an Afforestation, Reforestation and Revegetation (ARR). ‘Fideicomiso Financiero Forestal Montes
del Este’ project is a single GHG Project.
• Sectoral scope: 14 (Agriculture, Forestry, Land Use)

• Category: Afforestation, Reforestation and Revegetation (ARR)
• Activity type: establishment of forests on land that had previously been under grassland for more
than 50 years.
• Fideicomiso Financiero Forestal Montes del Este Project is a single GHG Project.
1.3 Project Eligibility
The project is eligible under the scope of the VCS Program as the project includes AFOLU activities (project
category ARR) which are supported by a methodology approved under the VCS Program.
The project was designed in accordance with the VCS General Requirements (VCS Standard v4.2) and it
complies with the specific AFOLU ARR project category requirement that the project area was not cleared
of native ecosystems to create GHG credits. The grassland vegetation dominating before project start
within project boundaries is not the native ecosystem of the land. The native condition was modified by
the introduction of beef cattle and sheep in the 17th and 19th centuries, respectively, and by the
introduction of exotic species during the last three centuries.
The project is located over degraded pasture areas, in areas categorized as “forest priority soils”.
According to Article 5 paragraph A of Forestry Law No. 15,939, " forestry priority areas are considered
"those soils that, due to their properties, aptitude, climate, location and other characteristics, are
unsuitable for any other permanent and profitable exploitation or use"1. Uruguay, by means of this Law
and its associated norms, recognizes the need to take advantage of this type of soils and has promoted
for years the implantation of forests over them, by means of incentives such as: Subsidies and tax
exemptions. This has been strongly regulated by MGAP and the Ministry of Environment.
Regarding the ecosystem, the pasture vegetation with cattle ranching that dominated before the project
began is not the native ecosystem of the land. The native state was modified by the introduction of cattle
from Europe in the seventeenth century and, together with advances in transportation and the
meatpacking industry, substantially modified the ecosystems that were part of Uruguay's landscapes at
that time. The introduction of cattle, sheep and horses by the European colonization strongly modified
the original landscape of the Río de la Plata grasslands, generating a great loss of native grasslands, at
least in their pristine state2. In the case of Uruguay, the condition of the grasslands was altered with the
incorporation of cattle (non-native species) more than 400 years ago by Europeans, especially by
Hernando Arias de Saavedra (Hernandarias)3.
In fact, Felix de Azara (Spanish military man, naturalist and geographer), following his observations during
his travels in South America at the beginning of the 19th century, describes that what happens in natural
1 Suelos de prioridad forestal. 2021. MGAP.
2 Bilenga y Miñarro. 2004. Identificación de áreas valiosas de pastizal en las Pampas y Campos de
Argentina, Uruguay y sur de Brasil. p. XXVI.
3 INAC. 2011. Historia de la Ganadería Uruguaya. p. 1.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The proposed umbrella project activity consists of installing and operating two new wind power plants,
PER 1 and PER 2. PER 1 wind power plant has a total installed capacity of 48.6 MW and PER 2 wind
power plant has 28.8 MW installed capacity, totalizing 77.4 MW. Based on the technical data of the
equipment installed and also in the local wind assessment performed by Garrad Hassan, the load factors
of the two wind power plants are expected to be 41% (equivalent to 3,592 operating hours). Considering
the total installed capacity, the load factors and the wind power plants self electricity consumptions, the
expected annual electricity generation is of 174,552 MWh for PER 1 wind power plant and 103,438 MWh
for PER 2 wind power plant, totalizing 277,990 MWh/yr.
The project is developed in Rawson Department, Chubut Province, in the southeast region of Argentina,
namely The Patagonia. The GHG mitigation activity will be lead by GENNEIA S.A. Both wind power
plants are located in contiguous sites and controlled by the same operator.
PER 1 and PER 2 wind power plants aim at reducing Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions by delivering
zero emissions generated electricity to the National interconnected system. The proposed umbrella
project will contribute to the displacement of currently operating fossil-fuel based thermal power plants
also delaying the construction of new thermal power plants.
The baseline scenario corresponds to the operation and provision of electricity by the currently existing
power generation mix and, in addition, the potential thermal power plants that would have been built and
entered into operation dispatching electricity to the grid without the implementation of the PER 1 and PER
2 wind power plants. This scenario is the same as the one existing prior to the implementation of the
proposed project activity. Fossil-fuel based thermal power plants produce electricity with lower project
capital expenditures (CAPEX) than renewable power generation plants. Thus, for large scale power
projects, private investors had always preferred to participate in fossil-fuel thermal power generation
initiatives. Consequently, the CDM registration of the proposed umbrella project activity (77.4 MW total
installed capacity) will contribute to mitigate climate change by supplying zero GHG emissions electricity
to the grid (neither fossil-fuels are used to generate electricity nor to operate the wind power plants),
displacing fossil-fuel based power plants (CO emitters derived from the oxidation of fossil-fuels) and 2
showing an alternative way for private investors to participate and promote large scale power generation
by means of renewable energy sources.
The emission reductions are estimated according to the actual start date of the plants (1 January 2012 for
PER 1 and 20 January 2012 for PER 2). Thus actual generation has been 163,074 MWh for PER 1 and
91,252 MWh for PER 2 until the end of the crediting period (6 December 2012). Corresponding emission
reductions are 121,462 tCO for PER 1 and 67,967 tCO for PER 2 (using the 2012 grid emission factor). 2 2
PER 1 and PER 2 wind power plants contribution to sustainable development could be observed at the
local, regional and global levels, since it will bring clean energy to the national grid, will avoid local
pollutant emissions derived from fossil-fuel based thermal power generation, will contribute to cover part
of the national energy demand with low electricity generation costs, will preserve non-renewable
resources as an economic value and energetic assurance for those cases where there are no existing
alternatives to fossil-fuel consumption, will increase the local employment levels during the construction
phase activities, and will implement a state-of-the-art technology for power generation and grid
distribution, at a large scale not yet implemented as such in the country.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The sectoral scope is number 1, Energy Industries (Renewable /Non-renewable sources), and the project
type is wind energy. The project activity is not a grouped project.

1.18 Additional Information Relevant to the Project
Leakage Management
The project is being implemented on low productive grasslands land and / or low productive
croplands (in absence of modern technology and agriculture equipment. Post carrying out
preliminary surveying activity in the project area and as realized via GIS analysis of past 10
years; the amount of vegetation to support grazing activity in the project area is negligible and
therefore, there will be little or no displacement of pre-project activity leading to minimum or no

Commercially Sensitive Information
No commercially sensitive information has been excluded from the public version of the project
description. Any detailed version of commercially sensitive information will be produced before
the VVB as per requirement.
Further Information
There is no additional information to the Project that was not already presented in other
sections.
2 SAFEGUARDS
2.1 No Net Harm
Summarize any potential negative environmental and socio-economic impacts and the steps
taken to mitigate them
The project is designed to have a positive impact on the environment and socio-economic
conditions by improving the local ecological conditions through nucleus estate tenera
plantations and there is no potential negative impact on the environmental or socio-economic
conditions. This project does not make use of any such fertilizers, pesticides, etc. which are
considered harmful to the environment and leads to biodegradation.
This project also improves the economic conditions of the local communities over a period of
time and beyond the project's lifetime. In case, any stakeholder wishes to withdraw their
participation in the program at any stage of the project, there will be no significant impact on
the overall project outcomes. Moreover, such withdrawals will be notified to the VVB at the time
of Validation/Verification incident.
19

Project Description: VCS Version 4.2
2.2 Local Stakeholders Consultation
Describe the process for, and the outcomes from, the local stakeholder consultation conducted
prior to the joint validation and verification. Include details on the following:
General description
A local stakeholder consultation program was conducted in the project area (Nucleus estate,
Buvuma island) with the following objectives in mind:
a. Identify key stakeholders for the proposed project activity.
b. Spread awareness amongst the stakeholders regarding numerous benefits of the ‘OYU-
Tenera plantations by OPBL’ project.
c. Provide suggestions & explanations on Tenera planting and post planting management
activities.
d. Consult & develop a mechanism for addressing any unanticipated grievances of the locals
directly or indirectly involved in the project.
e. Enhance the project's design by incorporating feedback and suggestions from locals.
f. Increase the involvement of all locals in the proposed project for improving their economic
conditions.
2.3 Environmental impact
Summarize any environmental impact assessments carried out with respect to the project,
where applicable.
This project does not have any kind of negative environmental impact: instead it aims to
improve the overall microclimate of the project area.
Ecology: Tenera plantation has a significant impact on the environment as it serves as a carbon
sink, releases oxygen, prevents soil erosion, enhances soil fertility, balances water levels in
watersheds, preserves biodiversity, adds aesthetic appeal to the landscape, and contributes to
the improvement of the overall ecological balance.
Biodiversity: Tenera plantation acts as a habitat for a wide range of terrestrial flora and fauna
species, which play a critical role in maintaining the ecosystem's fundamental processes. The
presence of a diverse array of species not only enhances the resilience of the plantation to
external threats such as climate change and habitat degradation, but also creates a positive
feedback loop that further boosts biodiversity, thus further strengthening the overall ecological
stability.
Atmospheric Carbon Sequestration: Tenera hybrid, can absorb large amounts of CO over a 2
span of 20 years, making it a significant carbon sink.
An Afforestation, Reforestation and Revegetation (ARR) project activity does not come under
any such category that requires conducting an Environment Impact Assessment (EIA). The
plantations are not a part of the activity list that requires an EIA.

JOINT PROJECT DESCRIPTION & MONITORING REPORT: VCS Version 3
PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project and its Implementation Status
Guanaquitas hydroelectric project is a small run-of-river renewable small hydroelectric plant with
a total installed capacity of 9,741 MW, located at the left margin of the Guadalupe River in the
municipalities of Santa Rosa de Osos and Gomez Plata, Department of Antioquia. The energy
generated is sold to the National Interconnected System of Colombia. The purpose of the project
is renewable electricity generation to be supplied to Colombian power grid.
The project activity considered the production of clean hydroelectric power using a flow of water.
The project collects the waters of the Guadalupe River at 2,089 meters above sea level, driving
the water through an open channel to the sedimentation unit. The water passes through a closed
channel to a load tank, moving to a pressurized conduction penstock and a distributor, where the
flow is directed to one Francis turbine. The turbine is hosted in a surface power house with their
respective generator, valves and control panels. The substation is located besides the power
house. As the project plant is a run-of-river hydro, a reservoir is not utilized.
The project will generate electricity for the Colombian power grid with low emissions technology.
The power plant will have an effective capacity of 9.741 MW1(rated capacity of turbine2), with a
predicted power supply to the grid of 64.3 GWh per year. Thus, the project will increase the
supply of electricity to the grid, offsetting thermal generation with a renewable source of energy,
and consequently reducing greenhouse gases emissions.
The project was implemented by Guanaquitas S.A. E.S.P, a public services company created in
2008 with the purpose of assuming the electric energy generation, transmission, distribution and
marketing functions. The design, construction and installation were developed by the engineering
company HMV Ingenieros Ltda.
The plant started construction on 26/03/2008, started operation on 30/06/2010 (commissioning
date), and has been in operation since then. The project activity is expected to reach an
emissions reduction of 21,973 tCO2 per year and 219,730 tCO2 during the entire crediting period.
During monitoring period from 30/06/2010 to 02/10/2013 (both days included), the project activity
achieved an emissions reduction of 77,183 tCO2.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Sectoral scope 1: Energy industries (renewable - / non-renewable sources). The project is a run-
of-river hydroelectric power plant presented as a single project.

and further selling the generated energy to the respective Grid or for captive purpose. In this
process there is no consumption of any fossil fuel and hence it does not lead to any greenhouse
gas emissions. Thus, electricity would be generated through sustainable means without causing
any negative impact on the environment. The estimated annual average GHG emission
reductions from the project activity will be 17,567 tonnes of CO2 and total GHG emission
reductions for the chosen 10 year crediting period will be 175,670 tonnes of CO2. The crediting
period is renewable for a maximum of 2 times.

have otherwise been generated by the operation of grid-connected power plants and by the
addition of new generation sources.
